body_html:
rats! Python indendation!

I added the check because @girving asked me to add a check that gradients must be complex when inputs are complex in #6868

But, I'm not sure of a way to exercise complex gradients, @girving any idea? Since nobody complained, maybe we can just drop that check completely?

The original reason for PR is that it enforced that activation value and backprop value have the same type, but we wanted to mix types (float32, float16). What if someone decides to mix real/complex types in the future?

But, I'm not sure of a way to exercise complex gradients, @girving any idea? Since nobody complained, maybe we can just drop that check completely?
The original reason for PR is that it enforced that activation value and backprop value have the same type, but we wanted to mix types (float32, float16). What if someone decides to mix real/complex types in the future?
body:
rats! Python indendation!

I added the check because @girving asked me to add a check that gradients must be complex when inputs are complex in https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/6868

But, I'm not sure of a way to exercise complex gradients, @girving any idea? Since nobody complained, maybe we can just drop that check completely?

The original reason for PR is that it enforced that activation value and backprop value have the same type, but we wanted to mix types (float32, float16). What if someone decides to mix real/complex types in the future?
